Valero Refining-New Orleans, LLC



St. Charles Refinery



Risk Management Plan





November 7, 2007





Executive Summary



Introduction



This plan has been revised and is being resubmitted according to 40 CFR 68.190(b)(5) due to recent RMP review and audit.  With the addition of a new hydrogen plant, threshold calculations were performed to determine coverage.  These calculations indicate that the new facility is not covered, however, in the review process it was found that a misinterpretation occurred concerning chlorine cylinder coverage.  This revision is to identify threshold exceedance and adds toxic coverage in the RMP.  We are currently in the process of eliminating chlorine usage, replacing it with sodium hypochlorite solution, for our cooling towers.  In fact, one of our four cooling towers has already been converted to bleach and the other three are scheduled for conversion in the first quarter of 2008.

 

The St. Charles Refinery is owned and operated by Valero Refining-New Orleans, LLC, formerly owned and operated by Orion Refining Corporation.  The St. Charles Refinery is currently operating its Crude Unit, Vacuum Unit, Delayed Coking Unit, Milli-Second Catalytic Cracker (MSCC), Gasoline Desulfurization Unit (GDU), Alkylation Unit, three Hydrodesulfurization Units, a Hydrogen Plant, a Hydrotreater / Hydrocracker Unit, Flare Gas Recovery Unit, three Sulfur Units and associated utilities facilities.  



The purpose of this plan is to provide information about regulated substances and release scenarios at the facility, policies and programs to prevent accidental releases, emergency response planning, accident history and planned changes to improve safety at the facility.  Each of these aspects are summarized below and fully detailed in the RMP. 

 



Regulated Toxic Substances and Release Scenarios



The St. Charles Refinery has four cooling towers ? three of which are treated with chlorine gas.  One has eight (5) one-ton cylinders while

the other two cooling towers have two (2) one-ton cylinders each.  Each cooling tower has single cylinder gas feed systems with no more than two cylinders connected at any time.



Worst case scenario is the rupture of a single one-ton cylinder.  The alternate release scenario is the failure of a fusible pressure relief plug in a cylinder.



As was mentioned above, chlorine usage is being eliminated by the first quarter of 2008.





Regulated Flammable Substances and Release Scenarios



The St. Charles Refinery has six flammable substances in amounts estimated to exceed the thresholds for covered substances.  They are Propane, Propylene/Propane mix, Butane, Isobutane, Butylene/Butane mix, and LPG.  There has been no change in the quantities of these regulated flammable substances in the facility from the previous RMP submittal.

Using the worst-case scenario specified for flammables by the EPA, a vapor cloud explosion of the largest vessel containing a regulated flammable substance, the Butylene/Butane sphere, would have the greatest impact.  Although numerous in-place controls prevent such an event from occurring, none of those controls are considered in modeling the worst-case scenario.



The alternate release scenario was identified based on a review of existing Process Hazard Analysis documentation, a flange leak at the Propylene/Propane vessel.  No residential areas are located in the area of impact; however, a neighboring chemical facility would be affected if this scenario occurred.  A strategically placed isolation valve, an in-place water curtain safety feature, on site presence of a fire brigade, operator intervention, and other Emergency Response Team actions will reduce the distance of impact.



Prevention Policies and Programs



The St. Charles Refinery operates under the strict guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Facility personnel strive for excellence in PSM by thorou

ghly integrating PSM into the organization's culture.  The PSM program is designed to:

* Reduce the potential for serious accidents

* Increase plant reliability, efficiency and product quality

* Diminish the potential for releases with environmental impact



Emergency Response Planning



The St. Charles Refinery has its own Emergency Response Team (ERT) to respond to all on site emergencies.  This team would coordinate with the St. Charles Parish Department of Emergency Preparedness (DEP) personnel during any incident with potential for off site impacts.  Copies of the Emergency Response Plan as well as ERT planning activities and exercises are coordinated with the DEP Director on an ongoing basis.



Accident History



One reportable accident resulted in an on-site fire in the Coker Unit.  This accident occurred on January 29, 2003.  Coking is a severe method of thermal cracking used to upgrade heavy residuals into lighter products or distillates.  Coking produces straight-run gasoline (coker naphtha), diesel (light coker distillate), and a heavy distillate fraction used as catalytic cracking feedstock.  The fire in the coker unit was due to a pipeline failure resulting in release of hot heavy oil, with auto ignition of the product.  Damage on-site was significant.  Off-site impacts included temporarily closing two adjacent roads.  Environmental monitoring during this event indicated no hazardous air pollutants present offsite.  To limit the recurrence of coker unit fires, Valero Refinery has made improvements and upgrades to the affected equipment and revised the maintenance and inspection procedures.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Continuing compliance with PSM/RMP guidelines and regulations forms the basis of the refinery's commitment to ensuring a safe working environment for employees as well as a safe community.  The facility benefits from the use of the latest technology in its processes as well as the assurance of the finest training of its

employees.  Specific actions that will improve safety include:

? Evaluation of process changes using Management of Change procedures to ensure safety and health

? Continual improvement in safety standards through application of the PHA process

? Use of process controls such as vents, relief valves, check valves, scrubbers, flares, shutoffs, interlocks, alarms, keyed bypasses, emergency air and power supplies, backup pumps, grounding equipment, quench and purge systems and rupture disks to prevent or minimize releases

? Use of mitigation systems such as sprinkler systems, deluge systems, water curtains and neutralization to reduce the impacts of any accidental releases

? Use of process area detectors to quickly identify and respond to emergencies.





Management System



Hazard Assessments

The PSM Manager has responsibility for:

? ensuring that the offsite consequence analysis for each regulated process is consistently performed and documented in accordance with Sections 68.20 through 68.39;

? ensuring that selection of the scenarios to be reported in the facility RMP as required under Section 68.165 are completed; and 

? ensuring that the accident history for each covered process is appropriately documented and maintained in accordance with Section 68.142 and 68.168 of the RMP rule.



Prevention Program



The PSM Manager has the overall responsibility for ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant prevention program as required by Sections 68.65 through 68.87 and OSHA PSM requirements.  The Environmental, Health & Safety (EHS) Director has certain specific individual responsibilities as outlined in our PSM/RMP Policy Manual.  General responsibilities for the Prevention Program are listed below (see also the PSM/RMP Policy Manual). 

1. Process Safety Information (Section 68.65) ?Technical Services Manager 

2. Process Hazard Analysis (Section 68.67) ?PSM Manager 

3. Operating Procedures (Section 68.69) ? Human Resources Dir

ector and Operations Complex Managers

4. Training (Section 68.71) ? Human Resources Director, Operations Complex Managers, and Plant Employees

5. Mechanical Integrity (Section 68.73) ?Maintenance Director 

6. Management of Change (Section 68.75) ?PSM Manager and Operations Complex Managers 

7. Pre-Startup Review (Section 68.77) ?PSM Manager and Operations Complex Managers

8. Compliance Audits (Section 68.79) ?PSM Manager 

9. Incident Investigation (Section 68.81) ? Safety Manager, PSM Manager, EHS Director, and Operations Complex Managers

10. Employee Participation (Section 68.83) ?PSM Manager, EHS Director, and Human Resources Director

11. Hot Work Permits (Section 68.85) ? Safety Manager, and EHS Director 

12. Contractors (Section 68.87) ? Safety Manager, Contractors, and EHS Director



Emergency Response Program



In accordance with Sections 68.90 and 68.95, the Safety Manager and EHS Director are responsible for:

? designing, implementing, and maintaining the facility?s Emergency Response Plan,

? ensuring that all associated training is conducted and documented as necessary,

? coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community emergency response plan, and 

? responding to local emergency planners/responders when questions arise.



Risk Management Plan Preparation and Submission



The PSM Manager is responsible for preparing and submitting the Risk Management Plan information as required under Sections 68.150 through 68.185 of the RMP rule.



Risk Management Program Communication



The PSM Manager has the responsibility of providing RMP information to employees and the public as required under Section 68.210 of the RMP rule.



Note ? the RMP Submit error is the software indicating that butane/butane mixture is not flammable.
